Article Title: World’s fully biomimetic AI robot ‘Moya’ revealed with warm skin and human-like reactions; neitzens reacts ‘More AI marriages coming soon’
Article Text:
Source: X (Indian Tech & Infra)

Biomimetic AI robot Moya: The robot that feels warm and acts more like humans



World’s first ‘biomimetic AI robot’ debuts in Shanghai

When is Moya expected to launch, and the mechanism



Social media reactions to the world’s first biomimetic AI robot Moya



A Chinese robotics startup has revealed the world’s first “biomimetic AI robot”, a humanoid machine that doesn’t just look human, but tries to feel human too, with warm skin, human-like walking, subtle gestures, Cameras sitting quietly where eyes should be, and everything almost feels like a human. Her name is Moya, which suggests that she isn’t just a showpiece, but there’s real engineering and sophisticated AI underneath the eerie exterior.Still, she looks like a robot because of the skin texture, which looks like a faint plastic sheen. The movements are a little stiff, eyes don’t quite land right, but linger for a moment, and something changes. Disturbingly lifelike robots have been popping up more often in 2026. Moya might be the clearest sign yet that humanoid AI is stepping out of demos and into public life.One detail keeps coming up: Moya’s skin is warm, unlike a cold, metal-like robot. Droidup, the Shanghai-based startup behind her, says the robot maintains a body temperature between 32°C and 36°C. Li Qingdu, Droidup’s founder, reportedly believes robots designed to serve people shouldn’t feel lifeless. The idea is emotional connection and familiarity.Whether that actually works is debatable. A robot that feels alive but isn’t can trigger a strange, creeping reaction. The kind you don’t quite know how to explain.Still, Droidup seems serious about this approach. Moya is being pitched for healthcare, education, and public-facing roles. Droidup claims her walking accuracy hits 92 percent, though how that’s measured isn’t fully clear. That said, her internal skeleton, known as Walker 3, has a pedigree. A previous version reportedly won a bronze medal at the world’s first robot half-marathon in Beijing back in 2025.They allow her to track faces, read movement, and respond with what Droidup calls “micro expressions”. Tiny facial responses designed to mimic human reactions. Paired with onboard AI, this is why the company describes Moya as a “fully biomimetic embodied intelligent robot”.Moya is expected to launch in late 2026. The price is eye-watering. Around ¥1.2 million, which works out to roughly £127,000. The company reportedly sees robots like Moya working in public service roles such as train stations, banks, museums, and shopping centres.Comment sections have already lit up with uneasy jokes. Some say she looks like a burglar deterrent. Others admit they’d panic if she walked toward them in the dark. Designers have long known that near-human robots trigger discomfort. Perfect machines feel safe. Imperfect humans feel familiar. The space between is tricky. Humanoid robots are no longer just lab experiments. CES 2026 made that clear. But despite the hype, experts say we’re still far from household androids. She’s not here to replace humans at home. She’s here to test how comfortable we are sharing space with machines that almost feel alive.As reported by the SCMP, this AI robot is formed with an advanced AI allowing to perceive and act in the real world. Out of this, social media users react to this AI robot unveiled. With users reacting to the new AI robot unveiling announcement:More AI marriages coming soon 😂 Perfect to keep creepy neighbors at bay 😂Just wait for the first ai me too movement😂 She looks like she’s straight out of K-popThat's not close to a human, that's just uncanny
Article Summary: Chinese startup unveils world’s first ‘biomimetic AI robot’ Moya is a humanoid machine that doesn’t just look human, but tries to feel human too. She has warm skin, human-like walking, subtle gestures, Cameras sitting quietly where eyes should be, and everything almost feels like a human.
